title: Early & often: Clemson striking quickly in 5-0 start
text:
Early & often: Clemson striking quickly in 5-0 start Scott Keepfer , skeepfer@greenvillenews.com 2:33 p.m. EDT October 15, 2015 Buy Photo Clemson's Wayne Gallman breaks free for a 66-yard touchdown on the third play of the game against Georgia Tech on Oct. 10. (Photo: BART BOATWRIGHT/Staff) Buy Photo CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CLEMSON – The Clemson football team has made a habit of scoring early in games this season, and that trend continued last Saturday against Georgia Tech. 
On the third play of the game, running back Wayne Gallman took a handoff, swept left and dashed 66 yard down the left sideline for a touchdown that jump-started a 43-24 victory. 
The previous week, against Notre Dame, quarterback Deshaun Watson ran for 38 yards on the first play of the game and tight end Jordan Leggett scored six plays later for a 7-0 lead less than three minutes into the game. 
“We just have to deliver that first punch,” Leggett said. “And the offense came out swinging.” 
The Tigers have landed those early blows more often than not this season. 
Scoring early – and often – has become the Tigers’ modus operandi. 
Clemson has shown quite a penchant for lighting up the scoreboard in the first and second quarters, and those fast starts have proven a key component in the Tigers' 5-0 start and No. 6 national ranking in the Amway Coaches Poll. 
Consider: 
--Clemson has scored on each of its first two possessions in three of its five games this season; 
--Clemson scored 19 points in the first quarter against Georgia Tech, its most since scoring 17 first-quarter points against Oklahoma in the Russell Athletic Bowl last Dec. 29; 
--Clemson has scored first in every game this season, and has never trailed at halftime; 
--Clemson has outscored its opponents 50-6 in the first quarter and 70-17 in the second quarter; that translates to an average halftime lead of 24-5. 
But Boston College, which visits Death Valley Saturday night at 7 o’clock, may pose the most serious threat to that trend to date. 
The Eagles boast the nation’s top-ranked defense and have allowed just one first-quarter touchdown this season. 
“They get in your face and force the issue,” Clemson Coach Dabo Swinney said. 
Swinney would like to once again see his team respond with force in kind, for he knows that early success can be critical for multiple reasons. 
Being down 7-0 or 10-0 or 14-0 just a few minutes into a game places the bulk of the psychological weight squarely on the shoulders of the opponent. They’re playing from behind before they know what has hit them. 
On the other side of the field, an early lead can serve to stoke the fire, providing a confidence boost that leads to bigger and better things. 
But perhaps more importantly, it gets a home crowd fired up. 
“We want to get our crowd going early,” Swinney said. “The crowd’s great, but if you don’t give them something to cheer about, that doesn’t go well. That’s critical. 
“They become a factor because we’re making plays on the field.” 
Leggett, who has a team-best four touchdown receptions this season, says he and his teammate are inspired to keep the early mojo going. 
“They always say that we want to start fast and finish strong,” Leggett said. “And that’s what we’ve been doing.” Read or Share this story: http://grnol.co/1LvZvXc TOP VIDEOS
